Veratraldehyde is a crucial industrial component used to make important chemicals, drugs, flavours, perfumes, mosquito repellents and cancer-fighting substances. This research focuses on the continuous processing of veratryl alcohol to veratraldehyde using the catalyst system composed of SBA-15/TiO2/SO4/Ni. The objective of this study is to explore variations in continuous processing parameters and catalyst loading to achieve maximum conversion and selectivity of veratraldehyde. The catalyst was synthesized and then characterized using the X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier Transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area analysis, and transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and Temperature Programmed Desorption (TPD). The catalyst was successfully synthesized, and the results of these characterization procedures revealed its particular porosity structure and composition. By attaining maximum conversion and selectivity at a lower temperature of 90 °C, the continuous process highlighted the catalyst's energy efficiency. The findings demonstrated that the highest veratraldehyde selectivity and yield were obtained under optimal reaction conditions, including a reaction time of 2 h for the catalyst SBA-15/TiO2/SO4/Ni(8%). This catalyst produced the best results, with a veratraldehyde selectivity and conversion of 100 and 99.5%, respectively. In addition to optimising the reaction conditions, the catalyst's reusability was assessed by running the same catalyst through the reaction seven times. The outcomes demonstrated that even after numerous applications, the catalyst maintained good activity and selectivity. This shows the promise of the SBA-15/ TiO2/SO4/Ni(8) catalyst system for the selective oxidation of veratryl alcohol to veratraldehyde in terms of excellent selectivity, good yield, and reusability. Veratraldehyde could be produced industrially at low cost and with minimal impact on the environment thanks to this investigation of a continuous process. Strong stoichiometric oxidants are typically used to carry out the reaction, however they produce toxic waste [2,3]. Environmental concerns have hampered the development of simple room temperature techniques since O2 produces primarily water as a by-product when used as a stoichiometric oxidant [4,5]. Recently, a number of sectors have paid close attention to the use of heterogeneous catalysts [6]. Heterogeneous catalysts have an advantage over their homogeneous counterparts because they can be regenerated more easily [7]. The synthetic method has advanced more recently as a result of the increased usage of solid acid catalysts during the last ten years, such as clays and zeolites. Veratryl alcohol is converted into veratraldehyde through a process known as methylation, which currently uses crude oil as a source of supply. Veratraldehyde is used in the food and fragrance sectors and the price is 100 times more if the VAL is produced from biosources rather than crude oil [8]. Ti-SBA-12(Titanium based Santa Barbara Amorphous) and Ti-SBA-16 are a few of the catalysts to be mentioned for oxidizing olefins [8,9]. Ni/SBA-15 is used in methane reforming [10]. TiO2/SBA-15 for alcohol oxidation [11]. Cr/SBA-15 for anthracene oxidation [12]. Fe/SBA-16 for epoxidation of cyclohexane [13]. Tetralin oxidation using co-doped mesoporous alumina [14]. Co/MCM-41 for diphenylmethane oxidation [15]. High catalytic activity, durability, and reusability, heterogeneous catalysts have received much research for the selective oxidation of substrates produced from biomass [16]. Veratryl alcohol was the target of few attempts to oxidize it using heterogeneous catalysts like Co3O4 [17], and Co-ZIF-9 [18]. Utilizing heterogeneous catalysts like Co, Cu, or Ru in batch process was found to yield between 73 and 84% of veratraldehyde [19,20]. Similarly, 95% yield of veratraldehyde was generated using a Ru-imidazolite/CuO catalyst [21]. The rate of conversion of veratryl alcohol to veratryl aldehyde under homogeneous conditions using the Mn(Me2EBC)Cl2 catalyst, a cross-bridged cyclam manganese complex, and H2O2 as the oxidant was equivalent to 98%, according to investigations by Zhang & Team. It was shown that no radicals were created throughout the oxidation process [22]. Stucchi and colleagues reported the oxidation of veratryl alcohol to veratryl aldehyde under heterogeneous conditions using deactivated carbon as a catalyst with bimetals Au-Pd supported on it and O2 as the oxidant at 80 °C, which delivered a conversion of 40%. The conversion rate were affected due to the presence of methoxy group present in the solvent whole processing of veratryl alcohol [23,24]. Yu and colleagues were able to observe the oxidation of veratryl alcohol to veratryl aldehyde using a bimetallic RuCo/rGO supported catalyst with oxygen as the oxidant at 100 °C. The selectivity was 71.6% and the conversion rate was 98.8% [25]. Wu and colleagues used a bimetallic Au/Graphene Quantum dots/Fe3O4 based catalyst to convert veratryl alcohol to veratryl aldehyde, and the conversion rate was >99% [26]. Using a Ru/POM (Polyoxometalate) nano catalyst under 350 K with oxygen acting as the oxidant, veratryl alcohol to veratryl aldehyde was achieved at a transformation rate of 98%, according to study by Baguc and colleagues. The catalyst was not significantly affected by leaching or sintering [27]. An Au-Cu/Al2O3 catalyst was used by Stucchi and team to oxidise Veratryl Alcohol to Veratryl Aldehyde at 80 °C with oxygen acting as the oxidant, and the process yielded a 70% conversion [28]. Aldehydes and alcohols play a significant role in chemical industry sectors, and the selective oxidation of these alcohols over zirconium sulphate SO4/ZrO2 have received attention. Studies related to using MCM-41 and ZSM-5 as supports for CeO2 in the veratryl aldehyde reaction. Adding ZrO2 to MCM-41 (Zr/Si = 0.38–2.32) demonstrated good activity in the selective oxidation of veratryl alcohol [29]. According to the present study, the selective oxidation of veratryl alcohol in a high-pressure fixed bed continuous reactor using TiO2/SO4/Ni supported on SBA-15 catalyst with TBHP as solvent has not been documented yet. SBA-15 is a type of mesoporous silica material that has a high surface area and a well-defined pore structure. By adding sulfate ions to the material during its synthesis, it is possible to change the surface properties of the SBA-15, such as its acidity or charge. This can be used as the material for specific applications, such as catalysts or adsorbents. Additionally, sulfate addition can also improve the thermal stability of SBA-15 materials, making them more resistant to high temperatures. The sulfate ions can interact with the silica framework through electrostatic interactions or chemical bonding. The SBA-15 sample displays the predicted trends for the sample as a whole. However, after loading each of the catalyst components, namely TiO2, SO4, and Ni, a continual decline in peak intensity is observed, indicating a continuous loss in the orderliness of the mesoporous structure as a result of sequential impregnation and calcination. There is also a tiny change in the lines location, moving them slightly toward sharper angles (Table I). Previous researchers have hypothesised that this shift could be caused by the accumulation of oxides inside the pores of SBA-15 [32]. Given that the shift in the peaks can be seen even after loading modest amounts of SO4 and Ni-ions, it is likely that at least some of the shift in our case is caused by factors other than pore deposition. The high angle XRD diffraction of titanium-based SBA 15 catalysts with various molar proportions of nickel (4%, 6%, 8%, and 10%) are portrayed in Fig. 1B. The high-angle XRD in the 2θ range of 10°–80° demonstrated the reliability of the structure of the SBA-15 support. In accordance with a prior report, each SBA-15 sample only exhibited a unique broad peak in the 2θ of 10°–40° range. In excellent conformity with the prior outcome, this occurrence was attributed to the SBA-15 sample's amorphous phase [33]. According to earlier studies, amorphous silica showed a single broad peak at around 22.7 [34]. Conversely, the SBA 15 along with titanium did not exhibit that broad peak. Rather, the anatase phase of TiO2 is comparable with the sharp peak at 2θ of 20° and 22° (101), and weak intensity peaks at 2θ of 25.34, 32.87° (004), and 48.24° (200), which resemble the JCPDS powder diffraction pattern 21–1272. This analysis revealed that titania exhibits a very flimsy layer over the surface of silica rather than crystalline aggregates as no peaks representing Ti-compounds are apparent in the wide-angle XRD pattern of Ti-modified SBA-15. All catalysts represented the face-centred cubic phase NiO's three noteworthy peaks (111), (200), and (220) in well-resolved manner (JCPDS card no. #47e1049). The diffraction peaks (111), (200), and (220) of Ti on SBA-15 provided more evidence of the existence of Ti on its surface (PDF-01–071- 0299). The trace proportion of rutile TiO2 (PDF-01–072- 1148) was also perceptible. This could occur because Titanium can become oxide when oxygen is trapped to its surface and heated during calcination in an ambient of N2. Owing to the Ti-O bond length considerably greater than that of Si-O, comparable to that of W-SBA-15, it is apparent that the pore diameter increased when titanium oxide was incorporated to silica [35]. The obtained pattern lacks the distinctive peaks of an anatase structure connected to TiO2. It can be inferred from this that TiO2 was in a fine dispersion phase and that no assertive crystallites were formed. It is abundantly obvious from the comparison with the TiO2 XRD spectra that no diffraction lines for crystalline TiO2 anatase could be recognized. The outcomes of this research reveal that titanium is efficiently disseminated and that the various precursors had a minimal effect on the crystal structure. The (111), (200), and (220) planes of Ti can be liable for the diffraction peaks (PDF-01–071–0299). The very weak peaks that were assigned to the (110) and (200) diffraction planes as depicted in the nitrogen adsorption-desorption findings exemplify that titanium insertion had a minor impact on the pore characteristics of SBA-15. The presence of TiN on the surface of SBA-15 was previously found to be associated with high intensity and sharp peaks. In addition, rutile TiO2 (PDF-01–072–1148) appeared to be present in a negligible proportion. This is brought on by the oxidation of TiN during the high-temperature calcinations process [36]. Additionally, it was demonstrated that the peak intensity declines with increased titania or titanium chloride loading (i.e., with more modification cycles), which is compatible with the progressive loading of mesoporous and decline in mesoporous orderliness. The minor increase in peak angle with increasing loads is likewise consistent with the slight reduction in d-spacing. The XRD pattern asserted that the titanium inclusion influenced the amorphous SBA-15 into a crystalline topology. 3.2 FT-IR spectroscopy The FT-IR (Fourier-transformed infra-red) spectroscopy is an analytical technique used to analyse the functional groups. The tert‑butyl hydrogen peroxide decomposes into tert‑butyl cation and perhydroxy anion in the first stage. The perhydroxy anion binds itself with the catalyst SBA-15/TiO2/SO4/Ni in the second stage. In the third stage VA reacts with the oxygen in the catalyst and attacks the carbon having a positive charge to form veratryl hydroperoxide, which is then subsequently oxidised and rearranges to form the selective compound veratraldehyde. Again, experimental results have showed that at higher reaction time the VA further oxidises to vetratric acid. In this step, the lone pair of oxygen in veratryl alcohol attacks the proton in the perhydroxy catalyst and removed as water molecule. The catalyst can be collected and used again for the subsequent round of selective oxidation during the process. 5 Conclusion Successful synthesis of the mesoporous SBA-15 with titanium oxide 4 wt.% sulphate and different wt.% of Ni (4–10) was accomplished. Several characterisation approaches were used to describe the TiO2/SO4 and Ni (4–10%) loaded SBA-15 as it was produced. The findings supported the successful loading of Ni/SO4/TiO2 on SBA-15 and the production of those materials. The selective oxidation of veratryl alcohol conversion used the SBA-15/TiO2/SO4/Ni catalysts for evaluation in continuous reactor for the first time. The SBA-15/TiO2/SO4/Ni(8%) catalyst discovered optimal product selectivity, conversion and yield. The SBA-15/TiO2/SO4/Ni(8%) catalyst demonstrated a veratryl alcohol conversion of 99.5% and veratryl aldehyde selectivity of 100% under optimal circumstances (Catalyst quantity 3.2 g; reaction temperature 90 °C; TBHP:VA ratio=1.0, Pressure: 10Bar, Time: 2 h). The SBA-15-TiO2/SO4/Ni(8%) catalyst's recycling performance was evaluated up to seven cycles, and it was discovered that the catalytic performance was intact even after those seven cycles. This Ni/SO4/TiO2 loaded SBA-15 catalyst is economical and effective from an industrial standpoint when compared to pricey metal catalysts. In a world where sustainability and efficiency are becoming increasingly important, this innovative catalyst system has the potential to revolutionize the production of veratraldehyde and make a significant impact on the field. The results of this study have shown that the SBA-15-TiO2/SO4 2−/Ni catalyst system is a promising and innovative alternative for the selective oxidation of veratryl alcohol to veratraldehyde, and holds great potential for further development and optimization in the future. coredata.dc:description: Veratraldehyde is a crucial industrial component used to make important chemicals, drugs, flavours, perfumes, mosquito repellents and cancer-fighting substances. This research focuses on the continuous processing of veratryl alcohol to veratraldehyde using the catalyst system composed of SBA-15/TiO2/SO4/Ni. The objective of this study is to explore variations in continuous processing parameters and catalyst loading to achieve maximum conversion and selectivity of veratraldehyde. The catalyst was synthesized and then characterized using the X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier Transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area analysis, and transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and Temperature Programmed Desorption (TPD). The catalyst was successfully synthesized, and the results of these characterization procedures revealed its particular porosity structure and composition. By attaining maximum conversion and selectivity at a lower temperature of 90 °C, the continuous process highlighted the catalyst's energy efficiency. The findings demonstrated that the highest veratraldehyde selectivity and yield were obtained under optimal reaction conditions, including a reaction time of 2 h for the catalyst SBA-15/TiO2/SO4/Ni(8%). This catalyst produced the best results, with a veratraldehyde selectivity and conversion of 100 and 99.5%, respectively. In addition to optimising the reaction conditions, the catalyst's reusability was assessed by running the same catalyst through the reaction seven times. The outcomes demonstrated that even after numerous applications, the catalyst maintained good activity and selectivity. This shows the promise of the SBA-15/ TiO2/SO4/Ni(8) catalyst system for the selective oxidation of veratryl alcohol to veratraldehyde in terms of excellent selectivity, good yield, and reusability. Veratraldehyde could be produced industrially at low cost and with minimal impact on the environment thanks to this investigation of a continuous process.
